newsitem.title: CHINA: Far East bullish on LME copper and aluminium.
newsitem.headline: Far East bullish on LME copper and aluminium.

text.p: Far East metal traders said on Monday they were optimistic London Metal Exchange (LME) copper prices would continue their current rally, helped by tight supply in China.
Demand in China is set to increase in the short term, as physical supply in the country is tight, sources said.
Shanghai Metal Exchange figures show copper stocks at 17,524 tonnes, a level described by one Western trading source as "nothing."
LME copper finished Friday trading in London $38 up at $2,366 a tonne at the afternoon kerb, off the day's $2,375 high and despite a stock rise of 1,875 tonnes.
LME three-months copper was trading in Asia at $2,362/67 a tonne at 0330 GMT on Monday, with spreads of $76-80, a trader in Singapore said.
Copper is currently arriving in Shanghai at a premium of $120 a tonne, inclusive of cost and freight (C&F) over the LME cash price, a trader in the city said.

LME aluminium was trading in Asia at $1,625 a tonne, a Chinese trader in Hong Kong told Reuters, adding that high grade Western aluminium was commanding a premium to southern China ports, basis Singapore, of $110 C&F, and to Shanghai of more than $120 a tonne c&f.
Continued healthy demand in China, as well as a significant difference between the LME and domestic Chinese prices would help maintain upward momentum in LME aluminium, he said.
Aluminium on the Shanghai Metal Exchange opened up 100 yuan a tonne on Monday, at 16,100 yuan ($1,927) a tonne.
